May 2, 1907.
Brown Brothers.

May 15, 1907.

52-54 West 38th Street, south side, east of Sixth Avenue.
About 1911.

60-62 West 38th Street, south side, east of Sixth Avenue.
1911.

Sixth Avenue, at W. 38th Street ("H1" station there) as viewed from the No. 63 W 36th street building. The photographer is viewing northwestward towards Broadway and its cluster of garment manufacturing lofts and offices. The ornate white building is the No. 110 W. 40th Street building and was originally known as the World's Tower Building. To the left is the turreted Lefcourt-Manhattan Building.

January 30, 1929
Views 1,2
P. L. Sperr

Sixth Avenue, at W. 38th Street ("H1" station there) as viewed from the No. 63 W 36th street building. The photographer is viewing northwestward towards Broadway and its cluster of garment manufacturing lofts and offices. The ornate white building is the No. 110 W. 40th Street building and was originally known as the World's Tower Building. To the left is the turreted Lefcourt-Manhattan Building.

January 30, 1929
Views 1,2
P. L. Sperr

38th Street, south side, east from and including Broadway to
and including Sixth Ave.
November 2, 1929.

folder: Sixth Avenue - 38th Street - 35th Street, looking south, Manhattan, NY
title: Sixth Avenue - 38th Street - 35th Street, looking south

text:
Sixth Avenue, west side, south from West 39th (right)
to 38th (left) Streets, showing a station of the Sixth
Avenue Elevated Line at the latter point. At the right
appears the Princess Theatre and which became the I.L.O.W.M's
Labor Stage, to show the labor travesty "Pins and Needles."
The photographer's vantage point is the left structure,
No. 65 West 39th Street, located at the N. E. corner of
Sixth Avenue. For other general views of this area see
items listed under that address.
View 2 is from the street level and shows the details
of buildings forming this blockfront.

View 1: February 28, 1930

P. L. Sperr

View 2: June 1938

George D. Chion

Sixth Avenue, at W. 38th Street, showing the 38th Street station of the Sixth Avenue "El" in a skeletal form. The photographer is viewing same in a westward direction on 38th Street from a point to the east of the Avenue and across to Broadway. The large loft structures in the left center face on
the last mentioned thoroughfare.
March 23, 1939
Mr. Nathan Schwartz
New York Public Library
Neg No :i 13O70

Sixth Avenue, north from W. 38th Street, showing demolition of the old "E1" line. Note the interested spectators. The wooden planking under foot covers in the subway excavation that is proceeding also.
March 29, 1939
Views 1,2
P. L. Sperr

Sixth Avenue, north from W. 38th Street, showing demolition of the old "E1" line. Note the interested spectators. The wooden planking under foot covers in the subway excavation that is proceeding also.
